item.title: RuneForge - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

The Wanderer:

Anyone want to comment on my idea so I can receive some input on it? Like I said, I fear my view is a bit biased.

Sorry bud I have been trying to get an Engine system coded so I was a bit busy;

I feel as if I can program something to handle statistics, possibly just a python script that is split into different sets of files that are written into a zip for serialization. Maybe even a .jar; see I am looking into the programming aspects. Its going to happen but I usually think of how before I think of when and where.

Update!

Finished multi-player; but not walking just yet Engine system still in beta, but looking better than before. Has the capability of running tasks at a ‘Calendar Date’ (mm/dd/yyyy), at a constant persistent rate with a variance of 4 ms and just a plain run function.

item.title: RuneForge - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Kono-chan:

Where’s the “Like” button?

In your mind

New code snippet!

This is a neat way of handling chat options.

/*
 * To change this template, choose Tools | Templates
 * and open the template in the editor.
 */
package net.forge.entity.player;

/**
 */
public class PlayerSettings {
  
    /**
     * Public  - First 4 bits
     * Private - Second 4 bits
     * Requests - Third 4 bits
     */
    public enum CHAT_TYPES {
        PUBLIC, PRIVATE, REQUESTS
    }
    
    /**
     * 
     */
    public enum CHAT_STATES {
        ON, OFF, FRIENDS, HIDE
    }
    
    /**
     * The local chat settings which include what messages the player would
     * like to receive and not receive. Default is always [true, true, true]
     */
    short chatsettings = 0;
    
    /**
     * 
     */
    static final int[] REGEX_MASKS = {
        (1 << 5) - 1, ((1 << 9) - 1) - (1 << 5) - 1, ((1 << 13) - 1) - ((1 << 9) - 1)
    };
    
    /**
     * 
     * @param type
     * @param state 
     */
    public void setChatSetting(CHAT_TYPES type, CHAT_STATES state) {
        int regex = type == CHAT_TYPES.PUBLIC ? 0 : (type == CHAT_TYPES.PRIVATE ? 1 : 2);
        int mod = state == CHAT_STATES.ON ? 0 : (state == CHAT_STATES.OFF ? 2 : (state == CHAT_STATES.FRIENDS ? 1 : 3));
        /* Remove regex settings */
        chatsettings &= ~REGEX_MASKS[regex];
        chatsettings |= 1 << ((regex * 4) + mod);
    }
    
    /**
     * 
     * @param type
     * @return 
     */
    public int getChatSetting(CHAT_TYPES type) {
         short setting = chatsettings;
         int regex = type == CHAT_TYPES.PUBLIC ? 0 : (type == CHAT_TYPES.PRIVATE ? 1 : 2);
         setting &= REGEX_MASKS[regex];
         byte b = (byte) (setting >> (regex * 4));
         int bits = 0;
         for(; bits < 4; bits++) {
             b >>= 1;
             if(b == 0)
                 break;
         }
         return bits;
    }
}
        PlayerSettings settings = new PlayerSettings();
        settings.setChatSetting(PlayerSettings.CHAT_TYPES.PRIVATE, PlayerSettings.CHAT_STATES.ON);
        System.out.println(0xFF & settings.getChatSetting(PlayerSettings.CHAT_TYPES.PRIVATE));

item.title: RuneForge - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:9, topic:397077”]Here is an idea I came up with. The idea is that your character will have different statistics saved and you could create a separate highscores with these statistics.

Statistics:
Total time logged in, total monsters killed, damage dealt, damage taken, spells casted(maybe?), projectiles thrown/shot(maybe on this too), total miles walked (we could convert tiles to miles by saying that 1 tile is approx. 3 ft because 1 tile is a stride and one stride in real life is approx. 3ft), slayer tasks completed(may be able to convert this to how rs awards points for a shop if the majority of people would like it), fish caught, logs chopped, fish burned, fish cooked, ores mined, bars smelt, times died in wildy, times died in pvp safe zones, times you have killed another player in the wildy, times you have killed another player in a pvp safe zone, herbs cleaned, potions mixed, runes crafted, seeds planted, fires started.

The more skill orientated ones we might leave out as they could be almost innumerable and also your total experience points would kind of follow the same line. I would just like the community’s input on these ideas. I know I would love them, but I fear my view is a bit biased as I love statistics and charts. :P[/quote]

Easy to implement, I am thinking of using a HashMap<String, Object> then just having a interface with a set of public keys to link them between. Then the object could be easily serialized and sent via SQL blob. Whatcha think everyone?

Read full topic

item.title: RuneForge - 317
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Here is an idea I came up with. The idea is that your character will have different statistics saved and you could create a separate highscores with these statistics.

Statistics:
Total time logged in, total monsters killed, damage dealt, damage taken, spells casted(maybe?), projectiles thrown/shot(maybe on this too), total miles walked (we could convert tiles to miles by saying that 1 tile is approx. 3 ft because 1 tile is a stride and one stride in real life is approx. 3ft), slayer tasks completed(may be able to convert this to how rs awards points for a shop if the majority of people would like it), fish caught, logs chopped, fish burned, fish cooked, ores mined, bars smelt, times died in wildy, times died in pvp safe zones, times you have killed another player in the wildy, times you have killed another player in a pvp safe zone, herbs cleaned, potions mixed, runes crafted, seeds planted, fires started.

The more skill orientated ones we might leave out as they could be almost innumerable and also your total experience points would kind of follow the same line. I would just like the community’s input on these ideas. I know I would love them, but I fear my view is a bit biased as I love statistics and charts.

Read full topic
